awd_titl_txt: Feasibility of Quantum Information Processing with Neutral Divalent Atoms: Decoherence-Free (Magic) Trapping, Rydberg Gates and Rydberg Blockade
awd_abstract_narration:
We will build upon the latest advances in atomic and optical physics to  develop novel approaches to quantum information processing with neutral  atoms. We will study the feasibility of realizing basic elements of quantum computing architecture, such as quantum gates  and long-lived quantum memory with divalent atoms held in specially-engineered  "magic"  optical traps.

The research will be carried out in Nevada, one of the EPSCoR (Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research) states, underrepresented in the scientific enterprise.  The work will fulfill one of the  strategic goals of the NSF to "broaden participation and enhance diversity in NSF programs."
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit of the activity 

Quantum information processing (QIP) with optically-trapped neutral atoms has a number of appealing advantages: scalability, massive parallelism, long coherence times and reliance on well-established experimental techniques. Historically most of QIP schemes with neutral atoms have focused on alkali-metal atoms (atoms with a single valence electron outside a tightly-bound atomic core). Yet over the past decade there were new powerful developments with cooling and trapping divalent atoms (alkaline-earth and similar atoms), including attainment of degenerate quantum gasses and a rapid development of a novel ultra-stable class of atomic clocks: optical lattice clocks. Our work has focused on combining neutral atom QIP schemes with optical lattice clocks with the goal of improving the clock stability and improving the feasibility of QIP schemes.

Arguably the most successful demonstrations of QIP schemes have been carried out using Rydberg blockade, relying on strong interaction of highly-excited (Rydberg) atoms. However, the fidelities of such schemes are affected by a multitude of effects and require detailed understanding of underlying physical mechanisms to overcome detrimental decoherence. We utilized the tools of modern atomic, molecular and optical physics to develop understanding of common decoherence effects and to develop new approaches to quantum information processing with neutral atoms. We studied the feasibility of realizing multi-qubit gates using Rydberg states of divalent atoms. We developed approaches to decoherence-free “magic” trapping of atoms in optical traps and developed a decoherence-free Rydberg logic and quantum memory insensitive to otherwise detrimental trapping fields.  

Broader impacts resulting from the activity

The research was carried out in Nevada, one of the EPSCoR (Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research) states underrepresented in the scientific enterprise. The funding of the proposal fulfilled one of the strategic goals of the NSF to “broaden participation and enhance diversity in NSF programs.” The grant supported research and education of a postdoctoral researcher. The findings and results were disseminated through publications in refereed scientific journals, conference presentations, and the Internet. 

 


Last Modified: 07/08/2015
Modified by: Andrei Derevianko
